question:
(a) Give an account of the economic importance or rocks

(b) Describe the characteristics and mode of formation of igneous rocks
answer:
(a) Economic importance of rocks:

(i) The appearance and characteristic features of the land are influenced by the type of underlying rock

(ii) Rocks give rise to either highlands or lowlands e.g basement complex: rock give rise to highlands, while sedimentary rocks gi ie rise to lowlands

(iii) Most of the rock types are rich sources of minerals e.g petroleum is formed from sedimentary rock while gold is from igneous rock

(iv) Rocks Gan be quarried to form gravel used in house and road construction

(b) Characteristics of Igneous rock are:

(i) They exist in crystals i.e they are crystaline in structure

(ii) They do not occur in layer or strata

(iii) They do not contain fossils Mode of formation of Igneous rock: Igneous rock is formed from the cooling and solidification of molten magma ejected from below the earth crust. If the molten magma cools before it reaches the surface of the soil, it is called plutonic or intrusive igneous rock, e.g granite. But if it cools on the surface of the earth, it is called extrusive or volcanic igneous rock, e.g Basalt rock.

question:
With the aid of well-labelled diagrams describe three main differences between the landform of any two of the following pairs

(a) Zeugens and yardangs

(b) Waterfalls and gorges

(c) Ria coasts and fiord coasts

(d) Levees and deltas.
answer:
(a) Three main differences between Zeugen and Yardangs:

(i) in Zeugen, the hard and soft layer of rocks are arranged in horizontal bands while those ef yardangs are arranged in vertical bands.

(ii) In Zeugen there must be lines of fissure in order for wind abras to perform its work but in yardangs, there will be re. lines of fissure

(iii) Yardangs are easy to form than Zeugen. 

(b) Differences between fiord coast and ria coast:

(i) Fiord coasts have been glaciated, rias have not

(ii) The sides of fiord are higher and steeper than those of ria

(iii) The ria gets deeper at its seaward end whereas the deepest part of a fiord is usually some distance up the fiord

(iv) Fiords are deeper than ria coasts.

question:
Describe either the Tropical Monsoon or the Cool Temperate Western Margin (British type) climatic region under the following headings
(a) Climate
(b) Vegetation
(c) Human activities
answer:
(a) Climate of cool temperate western margin (British type): The mean annual temperature is 13°C. The warmest month is 17°C while the coldest month is 4°C. Climate is very good for mental alertness and maximum comfort. Rainfall is between 600-800mm.

(b) Vegetation: Presence of deciduous forest - trees shed their leaves in the cold season to protect themselves against the winter snow and frost. Tempe-rate hardwood include oak, elm, ash, birch, beech horn bean, eucalyptus and horse chestnut.

(c) Human Activities, the main human activities are;

(i) Marketing and gardening Vegetable farms located in city centres where crops like cucumber, beet root, cauliflower, lettuce are cultivated

(ii) Mixed farming: Wheat barley are the main arable crops grown while cattle especially dairy, beef, cattle, sheep, pigs are reared

question:
Choose any one of the following vegetation types:

(a) Cool temperature eastern margin (Laurentian type)

(b) Temperate grassland

(c) Tropical rainforest

Describe the vegetation type chosen under the following headings
(i) location
(ii) vegetation characteristics
(iii) economic importance
answer:
(a) (i) Location of Tropical Rain Forest: Tropical forest is located between latitudes 5° and 1 C'° k:orth and South of the equator. The vegetation is found in Amazon basin of South America, the Coast of West Africa, Zaire, Malaysia, Indonesia and Columbia.

(b) Characteristics of Rain Forest are:

(i) The forest is green throughout the year

(ii) It contains very many families and species of trees including lianas or climbers and epiphytes

(iii) There are three distinct lavers of trees, i.e the top layer, middle layer and lower layers.

(iv) Economic trees Uke Iroko, Obeche, Mahogany, African Walnut, etc are found

(v) There are undergrowth at the base of the forest. 

(c) Economic Importance of the Rain Forest:

(i) Durable and valuable hardwoods are got from the region, e.g Ebony, Iroko, Obeche, Mahogany, etc

(ii) Cultivation of cash crops like oil palm, cocoa, rubber, etc

(iii) very little small scale livestock farming is practised.

question: Discuss any four ways in which man has interfered with his natural environment.
answer:
Four ways in which man has interfered with his natural environment are:

(i) Human intervention is caused by the increasing pressures with the rise in human populations, activities and demand for basic necessities of life such as housing. Such activities have caused modifications of the climate, landforms, soil, vegetation and drainage network in many parts of the world

(ii) Those human activities that are related to agriculture, grazing, mining, forest exploitation, water resources management, etc, have some damaging effect on the environment

(iii) Some of the well-known environmental hazards such as soil and coastal erosion, flooding, deforestation, land subsistence, atmospheric and water pollution are known to affect the environment.

(iv) Some aspects of human intervention have also helped to sustain the natural environment, e.g afforestation, land reclamation, artificial fertilization and irrigation schemes.

question: Account for the high population growth rates in the developing countries of the world
answer:
Reasons for the high population growth rates in the developing countries of the world include the following:

(i) Polygamous Marriage: African men believe in marrying many wives in order to give birth to many children so as to give or produce cheap labour for farming.

(ii) Child bearing was regarded as source of wealth and higher social class among members of the community.

(iii) Improvement in agriculture leading to plentiful and varied food supply

(iv) Reduction in inter-tribal conflicts and wars

(v) Knowledge of the causes of infectious diseases and how to prevent them

(vi) Better sanitation

(vii) Reduced infant mortality rate as a result of better health care

(viii) Early marriage among the vast majority of the people

(ix) Improved health services

(x) Modernisation and industrialisation make standard of living to improve.

question:
(a) Identify the respective functions of urban and rural settlements

(b) Discuss three areas of interdependence between rural and urban settlement.
answer:
(a)(i) The functions of rural settlements include:

(i) Agricultural activities as the main occupation of the people, i.e growing of food and cash crops

(ii) Pastoral farming as an occupation provided there is plenty of grasses for the livestock

(iii) Fishing function provided there are rivers

(iv) Small scale shopping

(v) Lumbering function provided there are forest trees

(ii) Functions of urban settlements:

(i) Industrial (production) function - presence of industries 

(ii) Commercial function which involves heavy trading

(iii) Administrative functions as urban areas are usually the sites of administration

(iv) Socio-cultural function as urban areas are places where schools, universities, foreign embassy offices are found

(v) Other primary occupations like mining or fishing can also be engaged in urban centres

(vi) Residential function as majority of people live in urban areas.

(b) Three areas of interdependence between rural and urban settlements are

(i) Rural settlements are sources of food for the urban settlements

(ii) Urban settlements are usually the sources of manufactured goods or food for the rural settlements

(iii) Urban settlements may also serve as administrative headquarters of the rural settlements.

question: With specific examples, describe the role of road transportation in the promotion of national integration in any country of your choice
answer:
The role of road transportation in the promotion of national integration in Ghana include the following:

(ii) Road transportation makes goods which are produced elsewhere available to other parts of the country

(ii) Transportation makes for regional specialisation in production. If goods are not moved, each region will produce less

(iii) Road development helps to reduce waste from over production e.g transportation of food from rural areas to urban centres

(iv) Construction of roads can also help in the development of large towns and cities

(v) It helps in national defense as troops can easily be moved by road to places where they are needed

(vi) it strengthens national unity as people from different parts of Ghana easily interact with one another.

question: With the aid of specific examples, discuss the factors that limit industrial development in Tropical Africa.
answer:
Factors that limit industrial development in Tropical Africa are:

(i) Inadequate Capital: Most of the entrepreneur are poor with low levels of savings. Banks are not wiling to give out loans because they do not have collateral security

(ii) Inadequate skilled manpower: Majority of work force are unskilled because of their low level of education and training So skilled labour is scarce

(iii) Small Market: Most industries in Africa have small market because of the small size of population and low purchasing power

(iv) Inadequate Infrastructure: Good roads, electricity, medical facilities are scarce hence low industrial development

(v) Shortage of Raw Materials: Raw materials are not locally available hence the industries have to depend on imported raw materials

(vi) Unfavourable industrial and administrative policies: Government at times makes some policies which are detrimental to the growth of some industries, e.g ban on the importation of wheat almost grounded all the flour mill plants in the country.

question: With relevant sketch maps, discuss the relationship between climate and vegetation in Nigeria.
answer: There is a positive relationship between vegetation and climate particularly rainfall and temperature. The intensity of rainfall is high in the extreme south giving rise to mangrove swamp forests. The rainfall decreases towards the north till when the rainfall is low in extreme north, e.g Borno area. The decrease in rainfall also accounts for the decrease in the thickness of the vegetaton from rain forest to grassland. In other words, the heavier the rainfall the thicker the vegetation will be. Hence south with heavy rainfall results in rainforest while the north with little rainfall results in grassland or savanna.

question:
Give an account of the factors that have aided the location of any three of the following

(a) Textile mills in Kaduna

(b) Oil refinery in Warri

(c) Pulp and paper mill in Oku Iboku

(d) Cement factory in Ewekoro
answer:
(a) Factors which favour the location of textile mills in Kaduna are:

(i) Availability of raw material. The raw material which is cotton is massively grown in Zaira and Kaduna

(ii) Presence of large market - Clothing materials produced from the mills are easily disposed off because of big market

(iii) Availability of labour. There is abundance of labour for the processing of cotton to its products.

(iv)Availability of power - Power, e.g electricity is readily available for normal operation of the plant. 

(5) Factor which favour the location of oil refinery in Warn are:

(i) Availability of raw material which is crude oil

(ii) Nearness to market as products produced from the refinery are used in the south

(iii) reduction in transportation cost. Cost of transporting crude oil is reduced as crude oil is processed within the area where the oil is found

(iv) Nearness to seaports from where the products can easily be exported.

(c) Factors which favour the location of cement factory in Ewekoro are:

(i) Nearness to raw materials which is limestone

(ii) Reduction in the cost of transporting the raw materials

(iii) Availability of labour

question:
Discuss the characteristics of either the Western Highlands or the North Central Highlands of Nigeria under tile following headings;
(a) Relief
(b) Drainage
(c) Soils
(d) Vegetation
(e) Human activities
answer:
(a) Relief of Western Highland: The area lies between 300 and 600m above the sea level. The hills'found include Idanre (the highest of 900m). Effon Alaye, Epemi, Akpata Hills, etc

(b) Drainage: The area of highland is drained by three rivers which flow directly into the Alantic Ocean. These rivers are Ogun, Osun and Osse

(c) Soils: The 'easement complex rocks give rise to ferruginous soils which are acidic but fertile. They have high clay content and good drainage

(d) Vegetation: The area is mainly rainforest in the southern part with luxuriant evergreen forest trees like I roko, Obeche, Mahogany, etc, while the Northern area is covered by derived Savanna with tall grasses and short scanty trees,

(e) Human activities: The main occupation of the people is farming especially crops like cocoa, kola, rubber, cotton and tobacco. Other are yam, cassava, etc. They are also involved in mining like limestone in Ewekoro, Ukpila, Shagamu. Other minerals include marble and gold. Gold is mined in Ilesha.

question:
(a) Discuss the problems of transportation on the
(i) Niger-Benue waterway
(ii) Lagos-Kano railway line

(b) Suggest possible solutions to these problems
answer:
(a) Problems of transportation on:

(i) Niger- Benue waterway include:

(1) Change in the volume of water with season. There is increase in volume of water during the rainy season which favours easy navigation but it is a problem during the dry season.

(2) Presence of rapids and cataracts - These are obstacles which inhibit easy transportation in the rivers

(3) Presence of debris. Niger-Benue waterway are at times filled with debris of forest leaves, broken branches of trees. These debris inhibit easy navigation in Niger-Benue waterway

(ii) The problems of transportation on Lagos-Kano railway line include:

(1) Long distance between the place involved. The distance between Lagos -Kano is too long and boring

(2) Problems with the rail tracks. Most of the rail tracks (Gauges) are worn out and outdated

(3) Presence of only one lane. Despite the importance of the route, it has only one lane as this poses a problem of allowing one train to wait till the other has passed Solution: As for the Niger-Benue waterway effort should be made to remove these cateracts and rapids in some areas so that navigation will be smooth. Solution: As for the Lagos-Kano railway line effort should be made to construct another lane so that one train doesn't wait for the other to pass.

question:
(a) Describe the methods of irrigation agriculture in either the Nile Valley or the Niger Valley

(b) Give reasons for the irrigation agriculture in any one of the river valleys

(c) Discuss the problems associated with irrigation agriculture in the river valley you have chosen above
answer:
(a) The methods of irrigation agriculture in the Nile valley are:

(i) Basin or flooding mathod - involves the seasonal flooding of the nearby lands in the Nile Valley during which the flood water is trapped and cannot flow back into the Nile Valley

(ii) Perennial Method - involves the damming of rivers to create artificial reservoirs which can supply water to irrigation canals at any time of the year

(iii) The Shaduf Method - The oldest method during which farmers collect water from river channel, either with a bucket or a water bag, and pour it on their farms.

(b) Reasons for irrigation agriculture in Nile valley are:

(i) To supply water to the soil as little or no rainfall is experienced around these areas

(ii) To fight drought as Egypt experiences desert climate

(iii) To produce crops all year round.

(c) Problems associated with irrigation agriculture in the Nile Valley are:

(i) There is the problem of fluctuation in the level of water used for irrigation purposes

(ii) Presence of excess of mineral salt like sodium which are injurious to plant growth

(iii) Over-flooding could be disastrous

(iv) Construction of many dams disturbs normal flow of water.

question:
(a) Discuss the main features of rotational bush fallowing in West Africa

(b) Describe the major factors affecting the practice of bush fallowing in West Africa

(c) Explain the problems associated with this farming method.
answer:
(a) The main features of rotational bush fallowing in West Africa are:

(i) There is abundant land

(ii) It is practised where the population is low

(iii) Farmers settlement is fixed as he only moves from one farmland to another

(iv) Only annual crops are grown

(v) Simple farm tools are used

(b) Factors affecting the practice of bush fallowing in West Africa

(i) Lack of sufficient land

(ii) Increase in population

(iii) Poor fertility of the soil

(c) Problems associated with bush fallowing:

(i) Destruction of valuable forest through land clearing and bush burning

(ii) It leads to fragmentation of land if there is increase in population

(iii) It allows for cultivation of only seasonal or annual crops like maize, yam, cassava, etc

(iv) The system can lead to soil erosion

(v) A lot of money, time and energy is spent on preparing the land for very little agricultural returns.

(i) Kariba

(v) Owen

(b) With reference to specific examples in Africa, discuss the importance of hydro-electric power projects to the economy

(c) Explain the problems facing the development of hydro-electric power projects in Tropical Africa.
answer:
(b) Importance of Hydro-Electric Power Projects to the Economy of Africa:

(i) Provision of power i.e electricity, e.g Akosombo dam

(ii) Hydro-electric project like Aswan dam also provides water for irrigation of farmland.

(iii) Dams are also used to control floods

question:
(a) Describe the methods of lumbering used in either Zaire or Nigeria

(b) Discuss the problems associated with the exploitation of timber in the area

(c) Using relevant examples, discuss the economic importance of lumbering in Equatorial Africa.
answer:
(a) Methods of Lumbering Used in Zaire are:

(i) The lumbermen search the forest to identify the particular tree species wanted

(ii) The trees are felled mainly by axe or hand saw or power saw

(iii) To cut a buttress tree a platform of 3-4 m above the ground is made on which the lumbermen stand to fell the tree

(iv) When the tree is felled, its branches are cut off and the trunks are carried by tractors to the nearest river, road or railway for onward movement to the sawmill of port for export.

(b) Problems Associated with the Exploitation of Timber in the Area:

(i) Heterogeneous nature of trees. Costs high amount of money to identify good ones

(ii) Difficulties in felling the trees because the trees are very close together

(iii) Trees with buttress roots are more difficult to fell

(iv) Many valuable species of trees are not felled because they are not known by the overseas consumers

(v) Rapids and fall! on the river make transportation difficult

(vi) Problem o deforestation without replacement. 

(c) Economic Importance of Lumbering in Equatorial Africa Include:

(i) The timber is_exported—as sawn logs for foreign exchange

(ii) It is used for the manufacture of plywoods and veneer

(iii) It is used for building boats, making furniture, and in the construction of houses and bridges

(iv) Wood is used as fuel. e.g for drying tobacco guinea savanna and smoking of fish in riverine areas

(v) It provides raw materials for industries, e.g paper, toothpick and matches industries

(vi) It provides employment to many people.

question:
Write a geographical account of ECOWAS under the following headings

(a) Aims and objectives

(b) Membership

(c) Possible solutions
answer:
(a) Aims and Objectives of ECOWAS include:

(i) To increase trade between the member countries

(ii) To cooperate in cultural areas such as education, music and art

(iii) To promote cooperation and development in other economic activities such as industry, transport, energy, etc

(iv) To contribute to a common fund which could be used to compensate countries that may lose economically as a result if the organisation and development of foreign investment

(v) To establish a common currency eventually.

(b) Membership of ECOWAS: It is made up of sixteen West African countries which are Nigeria, Benin Republic, Togo, Ghana, Cote d'Ivoire, Liberia, Sierra Loene, Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Gambia, Senegal, Mauritania, Mali, Burkina Faso and Niger.

(c) Possible solutions to these problems:

(i) Payment of annual dues should be compulsory as any member who refuses to pay should be suspended

(ii) Proper orientation among the members as there should be equality in the discussion and formulation of resolutions

(iii) A neutral body should be set up to execute programmes or projects for the organisation

(iv) President of ECOWAS should be rotated among the Heads of State of each country

(v) The formation of a common currency, should be implemented to facilitate inter-regional trade.
